snippet.textDisplay:
History Lesson: Some of the oldest depictions of dreadlocks actually originated from ancient Greece, specifically in Crete! Though many African cultures are the most widely known for wearing dreads, many other civilizations have had dreadlocks in their culture, including but not limited to: India, The Celts, Germanic tribes, Vikings, and the natives of New Guinea!


I hope you all learned something new today! :) I personally had no clue that much hair could hide in those dreads only to just fall out lol
snippet.textOriginal:
History Lesson: Some of the oldest depictions of dreadlocks actually originated from ancient Greece, specifically in Crete! Though many African cultures are the most widely known for wearing dreads, many other civilizations have had dreadlocks in their culture, including but not limited to: India, The Celts, Germanic tribes, Vikings, and the natives of New Guinea!


I hope you all learned something new today! :) I personally had no clue that much hair could hide in those dreads only to just fall out lol

snippet.textDisplay:
The last girl had "double ended" dread extensions. You can make them any color from synthetic hair but it is quite a process. After you make a ton of them, you take small sections of your natural hair (starting from the nape) and braid half of each double dread into your hair, as tight as possible to the scalp. Using two strands natural hair, the dread stands in as the thirds braid strand.
I've done this a couple of times waaay long ago, in like 2002 lol! It was fun but uncomfortable to sleep on for sure.
snippet.textOriginal:
The last girl had "double ended" dread extensions. You can make them any color from synthetic hair but it is quite a process. After you make a _ton_ of them, you take small sections of your natural hair (starting from the nape)  and braid half of each double dread into your hair, as tight as possible to the scalp. Using two strands natural hair, the dread stands in as the  thirds braid strand. 
I've done this a couple of times waaay long ago, in like 2002 lol! It was fun but uncomfortable to sleep on for sure.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm the same way, I've had so many hair styles and hair color that I'm like B** lets do this. Plus I cut and dye my own hair all the time I've only been to a hair dresser twice and I also got kicked out of an all natural hair school for wearing henna in my hair which their products were all plant based even their shampoos and toners. I've always thought about getting the dread locks that the last girl had where you just rubber band them to your hair for war weeks in Belegarth. But we shall see. I love these types of transformation videos.

snippet.textDisplay:
Straight hair doesn't loc, it mats. That's why white folks can't do locs - it's physically not possible. Only specific patterns of curly hair can loc, as their form naturally "locks" together without needing to skip showers or tease it up. Anything else is just dirty mats.

inb4 you come at me for "making it political", this is literally just proven scientific facts 🤷‍♀️ can't get mad at me for a non-opinion.
snippet.textOriginal:
Straight hair doesn't loc, it mats. That's why white folks can't do locs - it's physically not possible. Only specific patterns of curly hair can loc, as their form naturally "locks" together without needing to skip showers or tease it up. Anything else is just dirty mats.

inb4 you come at me for "making it political", this is literally just proven scientific facts 🤷‍♀️ can't get mad at me for a non-opinion.

snippet.textDisplay:
I look at this and know that (even if I wanted to) I couldn't do a style that I couldn't comb through. My scalp flakes as if I still have cradle cap there is SO much flaking (I have dry skin all over), and the flakes can't be removed without pulling them through the entire length of my hair.
I watched the entire shampooing video from last year and...yeah...I do ALL those things right, except I use far more shampoo, even using the method Brad said: I can't figure out how to get the Selson Blue I use onto enough of my scalp where all the dry, scaly parts are.


I wonder if you'd have any recommendations for those of us with very scaly scalps...more frequent than every 7-10 days washing? Or more medicated shampoo? More scalp-scraping in the brushing? LESS of all the above (which...I wash once every 7-10 days, didn't want to go for the expensive prescription hair, and don't brush my hair often).


So...any educational stuff on those things would be appreciated!
snippet.textOriginal:
I look at this and know that (even if I wanted to) I couldn't do a style that I couldn't comb through.  My scalp flakes as if I still have cradle cap there is SO much flaking (I have dry skin all over), and the flakes can't be removed without pulling them through the entire length of my hair.
I watched the entire shampooing video from last year and...yeah...I do ALL those things right, except I use far more shampoo, even using the method Brad said: I can't figure out how to get the Selson Blue I use onto enough of my scalp where all the dry, scaly parts are.


I wonder if you'd have any recommendations for those of us with very scaly scalps...more frequent than every 7-10 days washing? Or more medicated shampoo? More scalp-scraping in the brushing?  LESS of all the above (which...I wash once every 7-10 days, didn't want to go for the expensive prescription hair, and don't brush my hair often).


So...any educational stuff on those things would be appreciated!

snippet.textDisplay: The original purpose of dreads is the disregard for physical appearances and vanity.  It is, universally, a symbol of a spiritualist's understanding that vanity and physical appearances are unimportant. Both Eastern and Western Traditions hold that bodily, mental and spiritual energies mainly exit the body through the top of the head and the hair. If the hair is knotted, they believe, the energy remains within the hair and the body, keeping a person more strong and healthy. Apparently now it is a fashion statement that screams ignorance.
snippet.textOriginal: The original purpose of dreads is the disregard for physical appearances and vanity.  It is, universally, a symbol of a spiritualist's understanding that vanity and physical appearances are unimportant. Both Eastern and Western Traditions hold that bodily, mental and spiritual energies mainly exit the body through the top of the head and the hair. If the hair is knotted, they believe, the energy remains within the hair and the body, keeping a person more strong and healthy. Apparently now it is a fashion statement that screams ignorance.

snippet.textDisplay:
95% of black culture is derived from white people. Like, that's the hard truth. You have way more in common with the white people at the supermarket than you do with anybody from Africa. But it's a melting pot, so white people have their culture influenced by black culture, too.



There's nothing African about soul food, you eat the exact same stuff as white people. The only thing that makes it soul is because black people are so insecure about themselves that they feel the need to distinguish what they are doing from what white people are doing. Stop appropriating our culture, you culture vultures.
snippet.textOriginal:
